description: a(n) = T(n,n+2), array T as in A050143.
comments: Form an array having the first column all 1's and the first row the squares: m(n,1) = 1 and m(1,n) = n^2 for n = 1, 2, 3,.... Define interior terms m(i,j) = m(i,j-1) + m(i-1,j-1) + m(i-1,j).  Then the terms on the main diagonal are the terms of this sequence. - _J. M. Bergot_, Nov 16 2012Form an array with first row m(1,j)=1 and first column m(n,1)=n*(n-1)+1 for n=1,2,3...The remaining terms m(i,j)=m(i,j-1)+m(i-1,j-1)+m(i-1,j); sum[T(n,n){n=1,2,3..}]=a(n).  The first five terms in the main diagonal are 1, 5, 27, 147, 805 with partial sums 1, 6, 33, 180,985. - _J. M. Bergot_, Jan 26 2013
links: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
formula: G.f.: ((1-3*x)/sqrt(1-6*x+x^2)-1)/(4*x). E.g.f.: exp(3*x)*BesselI(1, 2*sqrt(2)*x)/sqrt(2). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Mar 28 2004a(n)=sum{k=0..n, binomial(n, k)binomial(n+1, k+1)/2} - _Paul Barry_, Sep 20 2004a(n)=n*R(n)/2, where R(n)=A006318(n) are the large Schroeder numbers. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jul 14 2005a(n)=Sum_{k=0..n}2^(k-1)*binomial[n,k]*binomial[n,k-1]. a(n)=(CentralDelannoy[n+1] - 3 CentralDelannoy[n])/4 where (CentralDelannoy[n]) is A001850. - _David Callan_, Aug 16 2006a(n)=(1/pi)*Int(x^n*(x-3)/(4*sqrt(-x^2+6x-1)),x,3-2sqrt(2),3+2sqrt(2)); - _Paul Barry_, Sep 16 2006(n+1)*a(n) -9*n*a(n-1) +(19*n-27)*a(n-2) +3*(-n+2)*a(n-3)=0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 16 2012
author: _Clark Kimberling_
